Award.AwardTitle: Uncertainty Propagation Methods for Networked Complex Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is development of a novel class of uncertainty quantification methods for networked complex systems. The fundamental and challenging uncertainty quantification problems remain unsolved, in particular combating the curse of dimensionality and solving uncertainty quantification problems related to large and multi-scale dynamic networks underlying modern day complex systems. The main challenge that lies at the core of analyzing and synthesizing the dynamic networks at the crux of modern day complex systems is: How do a collection of dynamical systems coupled through a dense wiring topology behave as a unit in the presence of uncertainty? The UB-SUNY team is developing of a suite of novel computational uncertainty quantification methods to tackle the main challenge and to enable accelerated design and deployment of complex systems.

This project will have far reaching impacts on research and the practice of complex system design and management across a wide variety of industries. Development of these methods will have an immediate impact on the community at large with beneficiaries ranging from ordinary users to system design teams in industrial, and academic environments. Our research is being integrated into the education of graduate, undergraduate and high-school students including under-represented minorities in science and engineering fields. These educational activities involve: 1) developing workshops and short course for researchers and professionals working in the area of systems engineering and uncertainty quantification, 2) developing seminar courses for undergraduates, and 3) incorporation of research results in graduate/undergraduate courses.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Buffalo
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Prior work related to Uncertainty Quantification (UQ) in nonlinear systems is mostly limited to effectively solving small-scale problems. For large scale systems, UQ methods based on decoupling entire state space into interconnected smaller state spaces have been recently pursued. A key limitation of these existing works is the approximation of the nonlinear nature of the system through the use of Jacobian at the initial condition.

 

- Outcome #1: First, we show that for small time evolution such methods can be useful, but for large time evolutions, the Jacobian information changes over the time and existing methods do not yield satisfactory result. This necessitates the development of novel state space partitioning schemes. 

 

 - Outcome #2: Second, we present two novel state space partition schemes that address above-mentioned shortcoming. We show the efficacy of the novel state space partitioning schemes on selected test problems.

 

When the number of interacting variables is large, it is prudent, if not imperative, to take advantage of special structural features of a decomposed system and come up with a substantial reduction in dimensionality to get a solution for analyzing the whole system.

 

- Outcome #3: We have developed the technique to linearize a given nonlinear system and perform state space clustering using standard graph clustering approach. We focus on different graph clustering approaches such as Spectral Clustering and Non-negative Matrix Factorization coupled with developed linearization techniques (Acitivity 1 and Acitivity 2), as methods of dimensionality reduction in nonlinear dynamical systems. We have compared the advantages and disadvantages in applicability, and effectiveness of these clustering technique. Numerical experiments have been performed on standard dynamical systems to compare the performance of these techniques

 

Most of Uncertainty Quantification (UQ) methods in nonlinear systems is only applicable to continuous variables. In our preliminary work carried out this year, we applied the developed techniques on Hybrid dynamical systems with limited success. Hybrid dynamical systems (HDSs) are an abstraction of systems that operate in multiple different operating conditions. HDSs are dynamical systems whose evolution depend on a coupling between state space variables (SSVs) describing operations of the system that can take values in continuum and SSVs (describing conditions of operation) that take discrete values. The HDSs problems are difficult and need specialized algorithms that are out of the scope of the proposed research. We carried out a preliminary study for this problem.

 

- Outcome #4: We present a method to enable UQ of HDSs. Specifically, we outline a computational pipeline to solve different types of Stochastic Hybrid Systems (SHS) with uncertainty in initial conditions. The developed method is based on a numerical integration technique Conjugate Unscented Transform (CUT) and discrete UQ technique.

 

- Outcome #5: We have started developing large-scale validation models in high-performance building modeling domain to validate our methods in real world large scale problems. 

 

2 Ph.D. students and1 Master student were funded by this grant. This grant led to 5 journal publications and 4 conference papers. A graduate level course included teaching module developed as result of this grant.

 


Last Modified: 11/05/2018
Modified by: Rahul Rai
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Prior work related to Uncertainty Quantification (UQ) in nonlinear systems is mostly limited to effectively solving small-scale problems. For large scale systems, UQ methods based on decoupling entire state space into interconnected smaller state spaces have been recently pursued. A key limitation of these existing works is the approximation of the nonlinear nature of the system through the use of Jacobian at the initial condition. - Outcome #1: First, we show that for small time evolution such methods can be useful, but for large time evolutions, the Jacobian information changes over the time and existing methods do not yield satisfactory result. This necessitates the development of novel state space partitioning schemes. - Outcome #2: Second, we present two novel state space partition schemes that address above-mentioned shortcoming. We show the efficacy of the novel state space partitioning schemes on selected test problems. When the number of interacting variables is large, it is prudent, if not imperative, to take advantage of special structural features of a decomposed system and come up with a substantial reduction in dimensionality to get a solution for analyzing the whole system. - Outcome #3: We have developed the technique to linearize a given nonlinear system and perform state space clustering using standard graph clustering approach. We focus on different graph clustering approaches such as Spectral Clustering and Non-negative Matrix Factorization coupled with developed linearization techniques (Acitivity 1 and Acitivity 2), as methods of dimensionality reduction in nonlinear dynamical systems. We have compared the advantages and disadvantages in applicability, and effectiveness of these clustering technique. Numerical experiments have been performed on standard dynamical systems to compare the performance of these techniques Most of Uncertainty Quantification (UQ) methods in nonlinear systems is only applicable to continuous variables. In our preliminary work carried out this year, we applied the developed techniques on Hybrid dynamical systems with limited success. Hybrid dynamical systems (HDSs) are an abstraction of systems that operate in multiple different operating conditions. HDSs are dynamical systems whose evolution depend on a coupling between state space variables (SSVs) describing operations of the system that can take values in continuum and SSVs (describing conditions of operation) that take discrete values. The HDSs problems are difficult and need specialized algorithms that are out of the scope of the proposed research. We carried out a preliminary study for this problem. - Outcome #4: We present a method to enable UQ of HDSs. Specifically, we outline a computational pipeline to solve different types of Stochastic Hybrid Systems (SHS) with uncertainty in initial conditions. The developed method is based on a numerical integration technique Conjugate Unscented Transform (CUT) and discrete UQ technique. - Outcome #5: We have started developing large-scale validation models in high-performance building modeling domain to validate our methods in real world large scale problems. 2 Ph.D. students and1 Master student were funded by this grant. This grant led to 5 journal publications and 4 conference papers. A graduate level course included teaching module developed as result of this grant.
